title-group.article-title: Application and evaluation of forecasting methods for municipal solid waste generation in an eastern-European city

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Environmental Engineering, Kaunas University of Technology, Kaunas, Lithuania.
2Department of Applied Mathematics, Kaunas University of Technology, Kaunas, Lithuania.

author-notes.corresp: Gintaras Denafas, Department of Environmental Engineering, Kaunas University of Technology, Radvilėnų pl. 19, LT-50254 Kaunas, Lithuania Email: gintaras.denafas@ktu.lt

abstract.p: Forecasting of generation of municipal solid waste (MSW) in developing countries is often a challenging task due to the lack of data and selection of suitable forecasting method. This article aimed to select and evaluate several methods for MSW forecasting in a medium-scaled Eastern European city (Kaunas, Lithuania) with rapidly developing economics, with respect to affluence-related and seasonal impacts. The MSW generation was forecast with respect to the economic activity of the city (regression modelling) and using time series analysis. The modelling based on social-economic indicators (regression implemented in LCA-IWM model) showed particular sensitivity (deviation from actual data in the range from 2.2 to 20.6%) to external factors, such as the synergetic effects of affluence parameters or changes in MSW collection system. For the time series analysis, the combination of autoregressive integrated moving average (ARIMA) and seasonal exponential smoothing (SES) techniques were found to be the most accurate (mean absolute percentage error equalled to 6.5). Time series analysis method was very valuable for forecasting the weekly variation of waste generation data (r2 > 0.87), but the forecast yearly increase should be verified against the data obtained by regression modelling. The methods and findings of this study may assist the experts, decision-makers and scientists performing forecasts of MSW generation, especially in developing countries.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Forecasting of generation of municipal solid waste (MSW) is the initial and essential step in planning MSW management systems. Forecast data serve as a basis in the development of existing waste management infrastructures, as well as their further improvement and optimization in terms of sustainability (Beigl et al., 2008). Inaccurate forecasts may cause problems, such as creating insufficient or excessive waste disposal infrastructure (transportation, processing, incineration or landfilling (Leao et al., 2001). However, the process of forecasting of generation of MSW is often problematic, since it is usually aggravated by rapidly changing parameters of waste management systems, especially in the areas of rapid economic development.
The choice of the method for forecasting municipal waste usually depends on the following criteria (Armstrong, 2001).

list-item.p: Amount and quality of available data (e.g. generation of waste, social-economic indicators).
Type of the data (e.g. continuous or random data).
Relationships of various parameters of waste generation and social-economic indicators.
Expected changes in the field of waste management.

sec.p: A review of previously published approaches (Beigl et al., 2008) revealed a high heterogeneity of applied models – from purely application-oriented up to highly sophisticated tools, in spite of the fact that the issues were similar. Seven groups of applied methods were identified: group comparison, correlation analysis, multiple regression analysis, single regression analysis, input–output analysis, time series analysis and system dynamics. As time series data of waste generation are dynamic in nature, and it is possible to employ non-linear tools in order to discern relationships among time series, artificial neural networks modelling has also been applied to waste management systems (Noori et al., 2009; Pham and Liu, 1995).

Beigl et al. (2008) concluded that the main criterion from modelling method selection is the type of waste streams to be investigated. In the majority of cases, correlation and regression analyses, as well as group comparisons, are the most beneficial modelling methods for testing the relationship between the level of affluence and the generation of total MSW or a material-related fraction. The algorithm for choosing an appropriate forecasting method has been suggested, based on the type of data and desired modelling output. According to this algorithm, total MSW generation is best predicted by time series analysis (when assessment of seasonal impacts is necessary), as well as correlation and regression methods.

Wang and Nie (2001) concluded that a rapid growth of the urban population and gross domestic product (GDP) (i.e. economic activity) were the major drivers of municipal waste increase. The linear regression model has been employed in the second half of the previous century, as one of the first attempts to forecast waste generation by more factors than only fixed growth percentage. Grossman et al. (1974) supplemented forecasting methods by including the following factors in the linear regression model: increase of population, income level and housing type. Later, Nagelhout et al. (1990) and Bruvoll and Spurkland (1995) provided an explanation that forecasting can be related to foreseen production level and consumption. Coopers and Lybrand (1996) have stated that accumulation of municipal waste can be defined by a simple equation, in which the amount of waste is linearly dependent on private consumption. However, a more thorough analysis of the relations among growth of economics and production of waste showed that different relation tendencies exist. The relation between the amount of produced municipal waste and GDP can be influenced not only by specificity of production of municipal waste but also by the fact that fluctuation of national income would not necessarily change the main household expenses (Christiansen and Fischer, 1999). The growth of the urban population has been found to have a greater impact than GDP on the total amount of MSW. With increasing income and the quality of life, MSW is changing in composition rather than increasing in total amount generated. Other factors that may affect the generation and composition of waste are the average living standards or the average income of the people, climate, living habits, level of education, religious and cultural beliefs, and social and public attitudes (Bandara et al., 2007; Marquez et al., 2008).

Time series forecasting models may be utilized for forecasting MSW generation in cases when substantial amount of historical data are available (Jalili and Noori, 2008). This method does not rely on the estimation of the social and economic factors; thus it has an advantage in comparison with the regression-based techniques (the prognosis of social-economic factors can be inaccurate as well). An even higher advantage of time series analysis is a capability of forecasting seasonal variations of MSW generation. Matsuto and Tanaka (1993) used moving average curves with the aim of determining the repeatability of the data. Katsamaki et al. (1998) analysed the daily values of MSW generation with the help of an autoregressive and moving average (ARMA) model. Each sequence of observations was modelled by Box–Jenkins stochastic models as a function of autoregressive, moving average and seasonal terms. For the overall time series, a seasonal ARMA model, expressed as (1,0)(1,1)5, was found to be adequate without inclusion of any seasonal terms. These authors have concluded that statistically significant data was obtained and the models were suitable for the analysis of MSW generation. Navarro-Esbri et al. (2002) performed time series forecasting (seasonal ARIMA) in three areas of Spain and Greece and concluded that short-term forecasting may reach an accuracy of 90% and mid-term forecasting up to 95%. Other researchers have utilized time series forecasting (ARIMA) for other than MSW waste stream analysis, such as waste consisting of electric and electronic equipment (Hsu and Kuo, 2005), recyclables (Chao, 2008) and waste materials from end-of-life vehicles (Giannouli et al., 2006; 2007).

Based on the comparison of the forecasting methods Beigl et al. (2008) argued that a forecasting tool based on the relationship between social-economic conditions and the amount of waste generated was more suitable than a single time series analyses (e.g. Skovgaard et al., 2005), which may be increasingly affected by measurement errors, especially in a short time series. It should be noted that the application of time series analyses is advantageous for special information needs (e.g., assessment of seasonal effects for short-term forecasts).

The present study aimed to select and evaluate an appropriate method for MSW forecasting in a medium-scale city with a rapidly developing economy, with respect to affluence-related and seasonal impacts. Many eastern European cities are currently undergoing significant transitions of their waste management systems, moving from landfilling-based MSW utilization to Mechanical biological treatment (MBT) and incineration-based advanced treatment facilities. Studies of the application of forecasting methods with the aim of producing the most accurate forecasts are very urgent and timely. In the present study linear regression (Beigl et al., 2003) and time series forecasting (Jalili and Noori, 2008) methods were applied and the consolidated application of these methods considered. Moreover, a novel combination of time series analysis techniques was applied.

sec.title: Object of the research
sec.p: Kaunas with 353 000 inhabitants is the second largest city in Lithuania and occupies an area of 157 km2. During 2008, 165 500 Mg of MSW (approximately 460 kg capita−1 year−1) were generated. In this article the term MSW refers to waste generated in households including fractions of bio-waste, paper, glass, metal, plastic and other combustible and non-combustible fractions.

The initial data for forecasting the MSW generation consisted of weekly mixed MSW collection weighing-based data per capita in Kaunas city during the period 2000–2007. The forecasting was carried out for the ten-year period (2008–2017).

Currently, the rate of household separation of recyclable materials in the city is very low (∼7%). For this reason, the data of mixed MSW (in the present case assumed to be equal to MSW), namely unsorted MSW as generated in households, were analysed. The recent changes in waste management strategy are expected to increase the source-separation efficiency in the long term. However, for the purpose of mathematical analysis, it was assumed, that the level of household waste sorting will remain unchanged; that is, the forecast rate of MSW generation will not be influenced by fluctuations in household sorting efficiency.

sec.title: Analysis of temporal variation of the MSW generation
sec.p: Methods of descriptive statistics were applied with the aim to describe the variation of the MSW generation rates. It was assumed that waste was collected during strictly defined points of time and the failure to collect waste during a single week had no influence on the amount of waste collected during the next week. Further, a single factor rank dispersion analysis was applied to determine the significance of differences of means from various data sets. In this way, temporal variation was assessed, with the aim of distinguishing a possible trend in data variation.

Further, the forecasting methods for MSW generation were selected based on an algorithm by Beigl et al. (2008). The aim of this article was forecasting generation of MSW with respect to affluence-related impacts, as well as to seasonal variation. Thus, the regression-based and time-series-based techniques were selected as forecasting tools. These analyses not only allow achievement of the desired aims, but also allow utilisation of the full potential of weekly waste management data collected by a local waste management company.

sec.title: Forecasting the increase in MSW generation with respect to the economic activity of the city (regression modelling)
sec.p: The forecasting model Life Cycle Assessment of Integrated Waste Management (LCA-IWM) (Beigl et al. (2003), available at http://www.lca-iwm.net) was utilised for the purpose of this study. The model has been developed as a result of a project entitled ‘The Use of Life Cycle Assessment Tool for the Development of Integrated Waste Management Strategies for Cities and Regions with Rapid Growing Economies’, conducted in the period of 2002–2005. During the course of the project, databases on MSW generation with respect to social-economic factors were created. The model was further developed according to formulas derived from historical data. The database used in the project contained time series cross-sectional data from 32 European countries and 55 major European cities within the period 1970–2001. It was hypothesized that the amount of MSW depended on both general development indicators (welfare) and a set of waste-related factors that have been partly proved by prior studies (Beigl et al., 2003). In addition the GDP, the infant mortality rate and sectoral employment indicators proved a significant impact.

In the first step of modelling, a region (city) with a defined social-economic status was attributed to a certain group of similar cities (with respect to the data presented in Table 1). During the second step, multiple regression equations using classical econometric methods for each of these groups were applied, assuming that the tendency of the generation of waste was similar within the group. The model is a system of three linear equations with up to four parameters. The developed model has a median relative error of 5.3% for the period of 5–10 years and 7.7% for 11–22 years. The median absolute percentage error was 8.0% (Beigl et al., 2003).

caption.p: The historical (2004–2007) and forecast (2008–2017) social-economic data of Kaunas city

tr.td: Percentage of persons between 15 and 59 years of the total city population (%)
Mean number of members in a household (persons per household)
The number of infants in city, out of every 1000 babies born in 2004–2007, who die before reaching age of one (babies per 1000 births)
The mean number of years newborn babies can be expected to live based on current health conditions (years)

Gross domestic product per capita (an aggregate measure of production equal to the sum of the gross values added of all resident institutional units engaged in production (defined as 1 US$ purchasing power parities per capita at 1995 prices) (US$ PPP at 1995 prices)
The number of infants in country, out of every 1000 babies born in a given year, who die before reaching age of one (babies per 1000 births).
Percentage of persons working in the agriculture as a percentage of the civilian labour force (% of total labour force)

sec.title: Forecasting the increase in the MSW generation based on historical data (time series modelling)
sec.p: One of the main objectives of the time series analysis was finding the consistent patterns of data variation (including the seasonal effect which determines significant fluctuation of the amounts of waste) and applying mathematical models for the characterization of the data. These mathematical models enable the forecasting of future time series, represented by the values of weekly quantity of MSW per capita.

Data on weekly generation of mixed MSW for 8 years (2000–2009) was available in Kaunas city. The model was ‘trained’ with the data from a period of 2000–2007 and validated during the period 2008–2009. Coefficient of determination (r2), random walk r2, Amemiya’s adjusted r2, Amemiya’s prediction criterion, mean absolute percent error (MAPE), mean absolute error and root-mean-squared error were utilized as measures of model accuracy. Several time series analysis methods, including simple exponential smoothing, double (Brown) exponential smoothing, linear (Holt) exponential smoothing, damped-trend linear exponential smoothing, Winters additive method, and Winters multiplicative method were tested on the formatted time series, based on the highest accuracy criterion. Non-parametric seasonal exponential smoothing (SES) and autoregressive integrated moving average (ARIMA) were selected as most accurate in predicting the time series (expressed as the highest values of the r2). The Dickey–Fuller criterion was utilized for testing the distribution of the residuals of the time series. For all of the below-described models, it was found that the residuals may be considered as ‘white noise’, that is, they were distributed normally.

sec.title: Seasonal exponential smoothing
sec.p: The application of SES required several transformations of the time series. The first-degree differentiation was carried out in order to negate the trend and reduce the process to the stationary form. Afterwards, a non-parametric model of the seasonal exponential smoothing of time series was created. In this method, the forecasting is performed by using the weighted mean of all time series values. Starting values were obtained by back-forecasting, that is, by forecasting the series in reverse order using a candidate model. The starting values for the back-forecasting model were set to the last value of the series.
The general form of the seasonal exponential smoothing model, forecasting k steps ahead is as follows:

sec.p: ARIMA combines the capabilities of autoregressive, differentiation and moving average methods. The most common ARIMA model includes all three above-mentioned parts and is expressed as follows:

sec.title: Assessment of temporal variation of MSW generation
sec.p: The weekly data and annual averages of MSW collected by the waste management company during the period of 2000–2007 are presented in Figure 1.

caption.p: Variation of MSW weekly amounts and yearly averages during the 2000–2007 period (kg capita−1 week−1).

sec.p: In order to test the significance of the yearly variation, the analysis of variance (ANOVA) was applied, due to its suitability to analyse the dynamics of trend variation with respect to the variations in factor values. The analysis of the means of yearly averages was carried out with the confidence level of 0.95. The first increase in the amount of waste can be noticed in the year 2003. The increase of the amount of waste could be attributed to synergetic effects of growing GDP (increased from 3600 € year−1 capita−1 in 2000, 4.1 in 2002, 4.6 in 2003 to 9.3 in 2008), growing affluence and average monthly wages in the Kaunas region, as well as a receding unemployment rate (decreased from 17.8% in 2001, 14.0% in 2002, 12.1% in 2003 to 4.2% in 2007). An enlarged collection service could also influence the amount of collected MSW, although this factor cannot be assessed quantitatively. Since 2006, up to 99% of Kaunas’ citizens had contracts with the waste collection company. Before that, the MSW collection was not based on the contracts; however, the MSW was still collected in the entire urban area, through the public container system.

The significance of differences between yearly waste generation data was assessed by dividing years into homogenous groups using the Tukey method. A significant yearly variation (P < 0,05) was determined, as 8 years were attributed to five groups of statistical difference. This also is evident from Figures 1 and 2 which show relatively low yearly variation between years 2000–2002 and statistically significant increase in MSW generation during the period of 2002 and 2005.

caption.p: Historical (2001–2007) and forecast (2008–2017) amounts of yearly generated MSW per capita, as modelled by the LCA-IWM model (based on social-economic forecasting).

sec.p: After establishing trends in temporal variation as well as the character of the historical data available for the analysis, the methods for forecasting the MSW generation were selected. First, the linear regression method supplemented by various social and economic factors was considered. The LCA-IWM model provided a platform for forecasting of the MSW generation depending on the above-listed indicators, as described in the Methods section. Second, the amount and quality of consequent data was sufficient to establish time series and apply appropriate analysis, as described in the Methods section. The application of the analysis of variance showed that a significant increase in MSW generation existed in a selected time frame. Moreover, a cyclic variation of generation of MSW during different months was discovered. The analysis of temporal variation suggested that a time series model could be designed to enable the forecasting of average weekly variation of MSW generation.

sec.title: Forecasting the increase in MSW generation with respect to the economic activity of the city (regression modelling)
sec.p: According to the principle of the LCA-IWM model, the city of Kaunas was attributed to the group of cities of high welfare according to social-economic factors (there are four such groups distinguished in the model: cities of low, average, high and very high welfare). Forecasting was carried out assuming that the GDP would increase by 6% within the year. The period 2004 (the earliest possible year for forecasting with this model) to 2007 was used for the initial data. It must be noted that the effect of the recent economic crisis was not evaluated, since this phenomenon was considered as a short-term effect. At the same time, it was not expected that any drastic decrease in GDP growth would equally influence the MSW generation rate. The sensitivity analysis of the model has revealed that changes of 1% in the initial GDP values may cause an uncertainty of 1% during the initial years of forecasting, but may increase to 5% in a 10-year period.

The forecasting results are presented in Figure 2. As a ‘zero’ scenario, the forecast based on the assumption that the increase in MSW generation follows the percentage of the increase of GDP in 2004 (equal to 6% year−1) was plotted. This prognosis was relatively precise for the period of 2004–2006. On the other hand, the tendency for 2006–2017 yielded unrealistically high forecast values. It is unlikely that in 2017 more than 700 kg capita−1 year−1 of MSW will be collected. This confirms the findings that MSW generation does not directly depend on the growth of the GDP. Beigl et al. (2003) concluded that the average MSW increase per 1000 purchasing power parities (at 1995 prices) is 12 kg capita−1 year−1. The European Environment Agency (EEA, 2008) concluded that during a rapid development of a city the growth in the MSW generation is faster compared to the GDP; however, during later years the increase in MSW generation gets lower even with a stable growth of GDP.

The application of the growth percentage, determined by the LCA-IWM model (equal to 2–3%), showed that the forecast value of the MSW generation greatly depends on the MSW generation during the initial year. The years 2004, 2005, 2006 and 2007 were tested as initial points of forecasting. Since this method utilizes a single point for further forecasting of the MWS generation, an adequate deviation was achieved in the forecast levels of MSW generation. The differences between the actual and forecast amounts of waste varied from 2.2 to 20.6%, although the error with initial point 2006–2007 was smaller (2.2–7.0%, Figure 3). This may be explained by some limitations of the model: it does not take into account the tendency for the growth of MSW generation.

caption.p: Historic (2001–2007) and forecast by time series analyses (2008–2017) amounts of weekly generated MSW per capita.

sec.p: The results of the forecasting confirm that in cities with a rapidly developing economy, it is very important to analyse the status of the current waste management system and compare the results of forecasting with those obtained by other methods. Failure of such assessment may turn into significant deviations of the forecast waste generation and consequently may cause many problems in the waste management system and the environment, such as over- or underestimated capacity of waste treatment facilities, overfilled containers, increased emissions.

sec.title: Forecasting the increase in the MSW generation by time series modelling
sec.p: The analysis of temporal variation suggested that a time series model could be designed to enable the forecasting of the average weekly variation of MSW generation per capita. Several types of time series analysis were applied, as described in the Methods section. Non-parametric SES and ARIMA models were selected as best predicting the variation of data. The principle of autoregressive methods allowed utilization of the data for the entire period, without losing information for seasonality forecasting and without putting too much weigh on data of lower reliability (2000–2003).

sec.title: SES model
sec.p: In the case of SES, initial values and smoothing weights were chosen for each model run. Model smoothing ratings were selected as follows (Equation (1)): ω = 0.26108, δ = 0.22442, smoothing level L0 = 8.95427. Seasonal smoothing components varied from −1.16391 (S1) to 1.24473 (S15).

The value of r2 defining the accuracy of the model (comparing historical data with forecast data for the period of 2000–2007) was equal to 0.889; that is, 88.9% of the whole data dispersion could be explained by the SES method. The MAPE was equal to 6.59%.

sec.title: ARIMA model
sec.p: In case of ARIMA, the model was designed on the basis of the autocorrelation and partial autocorrelation diagrams. The following cases of variables were selected: ARIMA(1,1,1)(1,1,3)52 (Equation (3)).
All the coefficients of the time series were statistically significant (P value < 0.05). The model (Equation (3)) was expressed as follows:
The r2 value was 0.874 and MAPE = 7.12%. The forecast amounts of waste by different models (kg capita−1 year−1) are presented in Figure 3.

It is evident that although both models were highly precise in fitting actual historical weekly data, they tackled the tendency of the waste generation increase differently. ARIMA showed an increasing trend, largely influenced by the growth of MSW during the period of 2004-2006. At the same time, the SES model has underestimated the raise of MSW in this period. Considering the advantages of the ARIMA model in the field of ‘white noise’ (random values) and by a better use of the SES method in areas where ‘white noise’ is absent, a combination of models was carried out.

The estimate

may be expressed as the combination of both models.

The weight coefficients α and (1 − α) were chosen by calculating the coefficients of linear regression between the values of historical and forecast time series. The weight coefficient of α = 0.4477 was chosen as the most precise one. The combination of models yielded the following values: r2 = 0.897, MAPE = 6.5%.

The forecast by the combination of ARIMA and SES provided the best reflection on the increment tendencies of the amount of MSW and seasonal variation. The yearly averages, calculated on the base of the weekly amounts of MSW, were plotted against other forecasting methods in Figure 4.

caption.p: Actual (historical) and forecast annual MSW generation per capita (kg year −1): comparison of regression and time series-based models.

sec.p: The validation of the model was carried out using the data collected from the period of 2008–2009. The results of the validation (summarized in Table 2) suggested that the accuracy of ARIMA + SES model was higher than that of ARIMA and SES.

caption.p: The estimates of time series model validation

sec.p: The application of time series method (ARIMA, SES and ARIMA + SES) for the characterization of MSW weekly generation was able to represent the historical data with an accuracy of 80%. However, forecast yearly cumulative values in some cases yielded a significant deviation in terms of predicting the increase of MSW generation. The time series models yielded the following forecast MSW quantities for the year 2017 (after accounting for modelling error): ARIMA 774–892 kg capita−1, SES 445–507 kg capita−1, ARIMA + SES 595–677 kg capita−1. The social-economic modelling (with 2007 as initial point) yielded a result of 578–642 kg capita−1. Thus, the results of forecasting using the social-economic model are within a standard relative error of the results obtained by the ARIMA + SES method. The ARIMA + SES method proved itself not only for the highest accuracy in replicating time series, but also in good correspondence to the results of the social-economic modelling. This suggests that optimal configurations of both regression and time series modelling options were achieved.

It may be concluded that the time series analysis method is very valuable for the forecasting of weekly variation of waste generation data, but the forecast yearly variation should be compared with other methods, such as forecasting by social-economic indicators, in order to determine the correct slope of the yearly increase.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The analysis of temporal variation of MSW generation was used for data screening and subsequent selection of the suitable method of forecasting. A significant yearly variation was determined (P < 0.05). The analysed period of 8 years was statistically attributed to several groups, representing various stages in the development of MSW management system. This analysis has revealed that using the forecasting method based on affluence-related parameters may potentially bring significant error to the results.

The modelling based on social-economic indicators is often used as the most convenient method. It was found that the regression-based model (implemented in the LCA-IWM model) adequately represented the increase of MSW provided that the initial point for the forecasting was successfully selected. This model showed the possible sensitivity (differences between the actual and forecast amounts of waste varied from 2.2 to 20.6%) to the external factors, such as synergetic effects of affluence parameters or changes in MSW collection system.

The analysis of the time series forecasting results showed that among time series analysis methods, the combination of ARIMA and SES yielded the highest accuracy (MAPE = 6.5%). The combination of the models allowed avoiding the influence by random values (SES) and the growth tendency (ARIMA). This model was particularly useful in forecasting weekly values of MSW generation. The yearly variation should be compared with other methods, such as forecasting by social-economic indicators, in order to verify the reliability of the forecast yearly increase.

The presented research demonstrates an approach of reliable forecasting of MSW with the relatively limited amount of data. It may be concluded that in countries with rapidly developing economies, it is important to utilize and inter-compare several forecasting methods, such as affluence-related forecasting supplemented with time series analyses. The presented methods may be utilized by the scientists and decision-makers during the planning process of MSW management systems, such as selection of technologies for MSW collection, treatment, and/or utilization.

ack.p: Authors are grateful to the JSC ‘Kauno Švara’ for providing MSW collection data. This study was partially supported by Swiss National Science Foundation (Project No. 128178).

ref.citation: ArmstrongJS (2001) Principles of Forecasting: A Handbook for Researchers and Practitioners. Boston, MA, USA: Kluwer Academic Publishers.
